hints_html: The general solution is a sum of a homogeneous solution and a particular solution. What happens to the homogeneous solution as \(t \rightarrow \infty\)? What solution to you need to find?
hints_latex:
The general solution is a sum of a homogeneous solution and a particular
solution. What happens to the homogeneous solution as
$t \rightarrow \infty$? What solution to you need to find?
hints_raw: The general solution is a sum of a homogeneous solution and a particular solution. What happens to the homogeneous solution as <math>t \rightarrow \infty</math>? What solution to you need to find?
question: 3 (b)
sols_html:
We seek a particular solution since the homogeneous solution will decay to 0 as \(t \rightarrow \infty\). As \(\sin(2t) = \text{Im}(e^{2it})\), we will look for a particular solution of form \(x(t) = \text{Im}(\phi(t))\) where \(\phi = A e^{2it}\) satisfies the ODE in complex form:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \phi'' + 2 \phi' + 5 \phi = e^{2it}\end{aligned}\]

so that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -4 A e^{2it} + 4 i A e^{2it} + 5 A e^{2it} = e^{2it}\end{aligned}\]

which upon cancelling the \(e^{2it}\) terms and simplification becomes

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A (1 + 4 i) = 1\end{aligned}\]

Solving for A we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} A = \frac{1}{1 + 4i} = \frac{1 - 4i}{(1 + 4i)(1 - 4i)} = \frac{1 - 4i}{17}.\end{aligned}\]

Now that we have A, we can find x by using A and Euler’s identity:

\[\begin{aligned} x(t) &= \text{Im}\left(\frac{1-4i}{17} e^{2it}\right) \\ &= \frac1{17}\text{Im}((1-4i) (\cos(2t) + i \sin(2t)) \\ &= \frac1{17}\text{Im}(\cos(2t) + 4 \sin(2t) + i (\sin(2t) - 4 \cos(2t))) \\ &= \frac{1}{17} \sin(2t) - \frac{4}{17} \cos(2t)\end{aligned}\]

The steady solution is \(x(t) = \frac{1}{17} \sin(2t) - \frac{4}{17} \cos(2t)\).
sols_raw:
We seek a particular solution since the homogeneous solution will decay to 0 as <math>t \rightarrow \infty</math>. As <math>\sin(2t) = \text{Im}(e^{2it})</math>, we will look for a particular solution of form <math>x(t) = \text{Im}(\phi(t))</math> where <math>\phi = A e^{2it}</math> satisfies the ODE in complex form:

:<math>\displaystyle \phi'' + 2 \phi' + 5 \phi = e^{2it}</math>

so that

:<math>\displaystyle
-4 A e^{2it} + 4 i A e^{2it} + 5 A e^{2it} = e^{2it}
</math>

which upon cancelling the <math>e^{2it}</math> terms and simplification becomes

:<math>\displaystyle
A (1 + 4 i) = 1
</math>

Solving for ''A'' we obtain
:<math>A = \frac{1}{1 + 4i} = \frac{1 - 4i}{(1 + 4i)(1 - 4i)} = \frac{1 - 4i}{17}</math>.

Now that we have A, we can find x by using A and Euler's identity:

:<math> \begin{align}
x(t) &= \text{Im}\left(\frac{1-4i}{17} e^{2it}\right) \\
&= \frac1{17}\text{Im}((1-4i) (\cos(2t) + i \sin(2t)) \\
&= \frac1{17}\text{Im}(\cos(2t) + 4 \sin(2t) + i (\sin(2t) - 4 \cos(2t))) \\
&= \frac{1}{17} \sin(2t) - \frac{4}{17} \cos(2t)
\end{align}</math>

The steady solution is <math>x(t) = \frac{1}{17} \sin(2t) - \frac{4}{17} \cos(2t)</math>.
statement_html:
Suppose the displacement x(t) of a damped mass-spring system subject to sinusoidal forcing of amplitude \(F_0\) is modelled by:

\[\begin{aligned} x'' + 2x' + 5x = F_0 \sin(2t), \quad x(0) = 0, x'(0) = 1.\end{aligned}\]

(b) Now take \(F_0 = 1\), and find the steady periodic solution (the part of the solution x(t) which remains as \(t \rightarrow \infty\)).
statement_latex:
Suppose the displacement x(t) of a damped mass-spring system subject to
sinusoidal forcing of amplitude $F_0$ is modelled by:

\begin{align*}
x'' + 2x' + 5x = F_0 \sin(2t), \quad x(0) = 0, x'(0) = 1.
\end{align*}

(b) Now take $F_0 = 1$, and find the steady periodic solution (the part
of the solution x(t) which remains as $t \rightarrow \infty$).
statement_raw:
Suppose the displacement x(t) of a damped mass-spring system subject to sinusoidal forcing of amplitude <math>F_0</math> is modelled by:

:<math>x'' + 2x' + 5x = F_0 \sin(2t), \quad x(0) = 0, x'(0) = 1</math>.

(b) Now take <math>F_0 = 1</math>, and find the steady periodic solution (the part of the solution x(t) which remains as <math>t \rightarrow \infty</math>).
